CSSRevert-layer.summary: The revert-layer CSS keyword rolls back the value of a property in a @layer to the value of the property in a CSS rule matching the element in a previous cascade layer. The value of the property with this keyword is recalculated as if no rules were specified on the target element in the current cascade layer.

remarks.para: If there is no other cascade layer to revert to for the matching CSS rule, the property value rolls back to the computed_value derived from the current layer. Furthermore, if there is no matching CSS rule in the current layer, the property value for the element rolls back to the style defined in a previous style origin.
This keyword can be applied to any CSS property, including the CSS shorthand property all.

-initial: Sets a property to its initial value
-inherit: Sets an element's property the same as its parent
-revert: Resets a property to the value established by the user-agent stylesheet (or user styles if any exist)
-unset: Sets a property to its inherited value if the property inherits or to its initial value if the property does not inherit
-all: Resets all properties to their initial, inherited, reverted, or unset state at once
